values.description:
I ported a few fixes from pull request #81

- used new ray projection API 

- removed material ambient component

- add `Object3D.getDescendants()` in `three.compat.js` for backward compatibility

Here are some of the new changes I had to make:

- fixed grid rendering

- fixed sprites in radial menu for gzweb mobile

- fixed incorrect joint visuals axis offset 

- fixed bounding box geom

- fixed transform control mouse picking (ray intersection no longer works with invisible obj, so used invisible material instead)

- updated collada loader and tweaked texture loading.

- updated collada loader to use normal map by default if bumptype not specified

- mixed ambient with diffuse for a consistent look with gazebo. 

- fixed submesh loading

Known Issue

- Some collada mesh's surface normals appear to be flipped, e.g. `house_3`. The problem could be the mesh itself - more specifically, the fault of collada exporters from 3d modeling tools. I imported and exported some of the meshes using a more recent version of blender and the models rendered correctly. I'll submit PRs to gazebo_models to fix these meshes.
values.title: Threejs r86

summary.raw:
I ported a few fixes from pull request #81

- used new ray projection API 

- removed material ambient component

- add `Object3D.getDescendants()` in `three.compat.js` for backward compatibility

Here are some of the new changes I had to make:

- fixed grid rendering

- fixed sprites in radial menu for gzweb mobile

- fixed incorrect joint visuals axis offset 

- fixed bounding box geom

- fixed transform control mouse picking (ray intersection no longer works with invisible obj, so used invisible material instead)

- updated collada loader and tweaked texture loading.

- updated collada loader to use normal map by default if bumptype not specified

- mixed ambient with diffuse for a consistent look with gazebo. 

- fixed submesh loading

Known Issue

- Some collada mesh's surface normals appear to be flipped, e.g. `house_3`. The problem could be the mesh itself - more specifically, the fault of collada exporters from 3d modeling tools. I imported and exported some of the meshes using a more recent version of blender and the models rendered correctly. I'll submit PRs to gazebo_models to fix these meshes.
summary.html:
I ported a few fixes from pull request #81

  • used new ray projection API

  • removed material ambient component

  • add Object3D.getDescendants() in three.compat.js for backward compatibility

Here are some of the new changes I had to make:

  • fixed grid rendering

  • fixed sprites in radial menu for gzweb mobile

  • fixed incorrect joint visuals axis offset

  • fixed bounding box geom

  • fixed transform control mouse picking (ray intersection no longer works with invisible obj, so used invisible material instead)

  • updated collada loader and tweaked texture loading.

  • updated collada loader to use normal map by default if bumptype not specified

  • mixed ambient with diffuse for a consistent look with gazebo.

  • fixed submesh loading

Known Issue

  • Some collada mesh's surface normals appear to be flipped, e.g. house_3. The problem could be the mesh itself - more specifically, the fault of collada exporters from 3d modeling tools. I imported and exported some of the meshes using a more recent version of blender and the models rendered correctly. I'll submit PRs to gazebo_models to fix these meshes.

values.description:
To test the PR:

open ` http/client/sdfViewerExample.html `

1. for the materials file, you can either use thee one that I made from [here](https://gist.github.com/MohmadAyman/4c2f904d279d63175acd361847ba03da)

Or you can generate the `materials json` file yourself using the `material-parser` npm package running those commands:

     1. `npm init` 

     2. `npm install material-parser`

     3. `node node_modules/material-parser/index.js <path to gzweb assets>`

2. select a folder containing a model <all it's assets included Textures, meshes ...etc>

3. View the model.
 
The materials for the object files are not handled yet, I'm working on a PR in THREE.js that would allow us to handle them.

***** set up grunt and cmake

* simple demo working

* materials added as an argument,  grunt files order fixed

* added a separate file for sdfviewer_gui, removed unused code from example html

* use only single quotes in karma and add angular mocks

* minimal gui used
values.title: Gzweb as sdfparser

To test the PR:

open ` http/client/sdfViewerExample.html `

1. for the materials file, you can either use thee one that I made from [here](https://gist.github.com/MohmadAyman/4c2f904d279d63175acd361847ba03da)

Or you can generate the `materials json` file yourself using the `material-parser` npm package running those commands:

     1. `npm init` 

     2. `npm install material-parser`

     3. `node node_modules/material-parser/index.js <path to gzweb assets>`

2. select a folder containing a model <all it's assets included Textures, meshes ...etc>

3. View the model.
 
The materials for the object files are not handled yet, I'm working on a PR in THREE.js that would allow us to handle them.

***** set up grunt and cmake

* simple demo working

summary.html:
To test the PR:

open http/client/sdfViewerExample.html

  1. for the materials file, you can either use thee one that I made from here

Or you can generate the materials json file yourself using the material-parser npm package running those commands:

 1. `npm init`

 2. `npm install material-parser`

 3. `node node_modules/material-parser/index.js <path to gzweb assets>`

  1. select a folder containing a model <all it's assets included Textures, meshes ...etc>

  2. View the model.

The materials for the object files are not handled yet, I'm working on a PR in THREE.js that would allow us to handle them.

* set up grunt and cmake

  • simple demo working

  • materials added as an argument, grunt files order fixed

  • added a separate file for sdfviewer_gui, removed unused code from example html

  • use only single quotes in karma and add angular mocks

  • minimal gui used

values.description:
@mohamd_ayman , could you please take a look? I built on top of your changes and:

* Merged from default
* Upgraded versions of grunt packages (to make `jsdoc` work)
* Fixed paths
* Now docs end up in `<root>/doc` instead of `gz3d/doc`
* Call `update` and `docs` scripts on the CI to make sure they work (added global install of grunt)

values.description:
Recently, we had an issue where a change to one of `node-gyp`'s dependencies broke the deploy/installation of gzweb. Officially, the fix is to lock node-gyp to a previous version of that dependency. See here:

[https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/issues/1299](https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/issues/1299)  
 [https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/pull/1300](https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/pull/1300)

...but that fix isn't merged/released yet. Adding an `npm-shrinkwrap.json` file to this package will solve that problem by specifying the right dependency at gzweb's level. npm-shrinkwrap is automatically parsed and handled by `npm install`, with no additional plumbing needed.

More broadly, this will lock all dependencies to known-working versions, so that such upstream breakages won't affect gzweb in the future. I've only tested this against 1.3.0, but it may be a good idea to add such a file to all branches, particularly all "old" branches which have fallen out of regular use/testing.
values.title: Added npm-shrinkwrap to lock versions of upstream node packages

summary.raw:
Recently, we had an issue where a change to one of `node-gyp`'s dependencies broke the deploy/installation of gzweb. Officially, the fix is to lock node-gyp to a previous version of that dependency. See here:

[https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/issues/1299](https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/issues/1299)  
 [https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/pull/1300](https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/pull/1300)

...but that fix isn't merged/released yet. Adding an `npm-shrinkwrap.json` file to this package will solve that problem by specifying the right dependency at gzweb's level. npm-shrinkwrap is automatically parsed and handled by `npm install`, with no additional plumbing needed.

More broadly, this will lock all dependencies to known-working versions, so that such upstream breakages won't affect gzweb in the future. I've only tested this against 1.3.0, but it may be a good idea to add such a file to all branches, particularly all "old" branches which have fallen out of regular use/testing.
summary.html:
Recently, we had an issue where a change to one of node-gyp's dependencies broke the deploy/installation of gzweb. Officially, the fix is to lock node-gyp to a previous version of that dependency. See here:

https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/issues/1299
https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/pull/1300

...but that fix isn't merged/released yet. Adding an npm-shrinkwrap.json file to this package will solve that problem by specifying the right dependency at gzweb's level. npm-shrinkwrap is automatically parsed and handled by npm install, with no additional plumbing needed.

More broadly, this will lock all dependencies to known-working versions, so that such upstream breakages won't affect gzweb in the future. I've only tested this against 1.3.0, but it may be a good idea to add such a file to all branches, particularly all "old" branches which have fallen out of regular use/testing.

values.description:
* removed http-server

* renamed ws_server to server

The http-server is causing me and probably you too some problems with the unneeded caching, and I couldn't really find a need to use two servers, is there?

This PR removes the `http-server` and uses the current `http` server in `gzbridge` to serve the application.

Running instructions: 
    1- `npm run start` this command is still the same, with the `port` as option.

    2- Navigate to `localhost:8080/index.html`
values.title: Use a single server

values.description:
Some additions to @mohamd_ayman's work on pull request #140:

* Serve `index.html` directly from `localhost:port`
* Commented code
* Use `const` and `let` on server code
* Check `server.js` with eslint
* Reword many of the console messages
* Serve websocket from the same http server which serves the static content - I'm not entirely sure this is ok, was there a reason for the separate port? @iche033
values.title: Additions to pull request #140

summary.raw:

* Serve `index.html` directly from `localhost:port`
* Commented code
* Use `const` and `let` on server code
* Check `server.js` with eslint
* Reword many of the console messages
* Serve websocket from the same http server which serves the static content - I'm not entirely sure this is ok, was there a reason for the separate port? @iche033

values.description:
This fixes issues #132 and #108

* Port `gzshaders` from @mohamd_ayman's  pull request #141 and remove `//` (comments) so the shaders compile
* Remove call to `computeTangents` (not needed)
* Remove `UVMapping` (not needed)
* Flip normals on vertex shader

![dem.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/1766715256-dem.png)
![height.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/1817264031-height.png)

values.description:
### Main changes

* This allows Iface to work without a Gui (issue #140) using events for the communication between them.

* I also unified all 4 emitters into a single one, partially addressing issue #136.

* Removed `LogPlay` from `Gui` as a first step towards using it independently

### Other smaller changes

* Moved test fixture loading to `spec_helper.js`
* Run eslint for tests
* Documented gziface

### TODO

This is mostly a proposal, if there are no objections to the changes here, I'd like to add a few more tests
values.title: Unify emitters, decouple Iface and Gui

values.description:
I pulled @mohamd_ayman's branch into this repo, merged default and fixed conflicts. There is a lot in common between this branch and another one I'm working on, `gz3d_embedded`, so I'm planning to take the common parts and break them into new PRs.

Meanwhile, I'll leave this here as an updated alternative to pull request #141

values.description: This is broken off pull request #141 with some added tweaks and testing. It assures proper support for scenes which have custom sizes, instead of always taking up the whole window.
values.title: Scene custom size
